Do like it when the No 1 highlight on a mining company's interim figures is the cash position

PM

· Net cash has improved to $114 million as at 31 March 2016. This is compared with $185 million net debt at
30 September 2015. Total liquidity of $474 million (circa ZAR 7 billion) comprised gross cash of $264 million, before
deducting the drawn term loan of $150 million and undrawn debt facilities of $210 million.

BE

In terms of operationally, the improvements are .... well, slim.

11:13 am
BE

Here's VSA Capital.

BE

Q2 production numbers released today from Lonmin (LMI) show an improvement in costs of 2.6% YoY and 5.1% QoQ to R10,390 for the quarter. No lost time fatalities during the quarter we believe have helped those costs though we do not expect such performance in the current quarter with two fatalities already, which require production interruptions while investigations as to cause are made.

Platinum sales rose 77.6% to 211,462ozs YoY, suggesting to us some stockpiled inventory was brought to market to take advantage of rising PGM prices during the quarter. Older Generation 1 shafts had a 22% decline in production in line with forecasts as these are on the path to closure. PGM prices proved relatively flat YoY at R11,035/oz.

In H1 results, LMI reports revenue of US$515m and a pre-tax loss of US$21m equal to 1.8c/sh. The cash position stands at US$114m of net cash at March 31.

In guidance for the year LMI predicts improved PGM prices but not so much that new total global capacity is incentivized across the industry to be built. Capex guidance was reduced from US$132m to US$105m. Sales guidance was re-iterated at circa 700kozs PGM’s.

We would hope the production ounce unit costs improvements continue. Rationalising production to a more resilient LMI is the way forward and we feel LMI appears to be on course for that.

BE

And Shore.

11:14 am
BE

LONMIN^ (LMI, NR, CNP) – Full-year sales guidance appears do-able, a little more work needed on costs; ship turning around, but needs favourable price and FX winds to go anywhere fast. Production in Q2 FY2016 was slightly down on both Q1 FY2016 and Q2 FY2015. However, Lonmin was able to reduce unit costs by 5.1% vs. Q1 FY2016 (albeit Q1 was impacted by the December holidays) and 2.6% lower than Q2 FY2015. Refined production and sales were slightly up on Q1 FY2016 and significantly up on Q2 FY2015 (which was impacted by smelter issues).

In relation to the H1 FY2016 P&L, Lonmin remained loss-making at all levels, albeit it is now only slightly loss-making rather than heavily loss-making. Operations recorded significantly reduced cash outflows, and thanks to the recent refinancing, Lonmin ended the period with US$264m of cash (albeit this was still down on the US$320m cash at the start of the period). Current assets totalled US$687m, dwarfing current liabilities of US$158m. Net debt was reduced to US$114m (from US$185m).

For the full-year, Lonmin reiterated sales guidance of c.700koz Pt at R10,400/oz PGMs (H1 FY2016: 361.9koz @ R10,668/oz). Capex guidance was reduced further, to US$105m (from US$132m). The sales guidance appears do-able, assuming no production hiccups, but there is clearly still some work to do on cost (which is essentially a case of running to keep still). All in all, the good ship Lonmin is showing signs of gradually being turned around, but it will be heavily dependent on having favourable PGM price and FX winds in its sails in order to go anywhere fast.

BE

So, still a lossmaking miner operating in South Africa and surviving by capex cuts.

BE

Still at the mercy of autos demand ( danger ) and other suppliers staying rational ( danger danger danger )

• The market’s focus will be on Lonmin’s ongoing cost reduction efforts, with the reduction in capex likely welcomed by the market. However, the upcoming wage negotiations may be a cause for concern with the current two-year agreement expiring on 30th June.

Aldermore Group PLC (ALD:LSE): Last: 193.31, up 6.41 (+3.43%), High: 193.40, Low: 188.80, Volume: 130.08k
11:19 am
PM

Etc

PM

We initiate coverage on five UK banks and transfer primary coverage of Virgin Money (VM) to Ian Sealey. The Challengers trade on 8.0x 2017E P/E and 1.2x 2017E P/tBV for a weighted average RotE of 12%. This compares to large-cap UK domestic banks on 9.3x P/E and 0.8x P/tBV for an average 8.9% RotE, despite superior growth prospects for the Challengers, in our view. We see attractive Challenger valuations as driven by misplaced concerns over the impact of BTL mortgage changes. Our order of preference for the Challenger banks is: Shawbrook (Buy, 340p TP), CYBG (Buy, 260p TP), VM (Buy, 405p TP), OSB (Buy, 320p TP), Aldermore (Neutral, 210p TP), and Metro Bank (Neutral, 2,120p TP).

PM

Impressive Growth Prospects
We see the UK Challenger banks offering attractive revenue growth of 17-23% pa over 2016-18, as they capture market share from a low base. In turn, we expect significant operating leverage to drive down cost-income ratios from 77% in 2015 to 50% in 2018. The secured nature of the portfolios, focused on asset finance in SME, and mortgages in retail, combined with a strong UK economy, should mean asset quality remains benign. We see this resulting in double-digit earnings and book value growth over the next few years.

11:20 am
PM

Strategic Positioning
The specialist lenders (Aldermore, OneSavings Bank and Shawbrook) have avoided direct competition with large UK banks by focusing on specialist lending via bespoke underwriting and strong intermediary relationships. In contrast, Clydesdale (CYBG) and Metro Bank do operate in the mainstream lending markets but have been able to raise cheap current account deposits via their branch networks in order to compete. CYBG has scale in its core regions (eg Scotland, North East), while Metro Bank competes on superior service and auxiliary revenue generation (eg safety deposit boxes). In contrast, VM operates in the main markets of mortgages and credit cards, but does not have an established current account franchise. VM is dependent on its trusted brand and scalable platform to compete.

PM

Buy-to-Let (BTL) and Regulatory Risks
Regulatory and political scrutiny of BTL mortgages has increased. Risks to the banks include a slowdown in lending (following the introduction of a stamp duty surcharge and tightening of underwriting standards) and higher risk weights (following a consultation by the BIS – although this isn’t our base case). While we expect a post 1Q16 slowdown in BTL lending, we think longer-term market strength will continue due to housing demand supply imbalance, demographics and attractive returns. In addition, the Challenger banks have a greater weighting to professional landlords who can invest in property through limited companies and are therefore less impacted by the tax changes. UK Challengers most exposed to the BTL market are OneSavings Bank and Aldermore.

PM

Challengers vs Incumbents
With fewer regulatory headwinds, little legacy conduct risk, superior promoter scores, a lack of inefficient legacy systems, more optimum branch network and stronger volume growth, we prefer the Challenger banks sector to the incumbent large-cap domestic UK banks. We are overweight the Challenger banks vs our neutral stance on large-cap UK domestic banks.

Drax Group PLC (DRX:LSE): Last: 293.20, down 20.6 (-6.56%), High: 306.40, Low: 293.20, Volume: 442.53k
11:26 am
BE

Bernstein downgrade on valuation.

BE

It being Bernstein, I can't quote too much.

BE

The three-par conclusion sums up the argument nicely though.

11:27 am
BE

Drax's share price performance in 2016 to date has been catalysed by four factors including improving oil prices, the announcement of an additional 1-year ancillary services contract with National Grid, the introduction of a capacity market mechanism for the 2017/18 delivery year and growing hope of a fourth unit conversion (and potentially a fifth and sixth unit conversion) given statements by the Chairman at the AGM. The future trajectory of power and gas prices is uncertain and certainly delinked from that of oil and the hope seeping into the share price on a fourth unit biomass conversion is unjustified in our view given the potential barriers, not least of which rests on convincing the Government to support it for further biomass conversions under the CfD regime.

BE

Having assessed the upside risks, there is clear additional downside risk from further weakness in power prices, driven by the NBP gas price, which will impact the economics of not just the coal units, but also the two biomass units on ROCs (which are linked to the power price). A scenario of 25p/therm gas for Drax would reduce our valuation by 12% to 220p.

BE

The valuation of the stock has diverged considerably from the fundamentals in our view, driving us to downgrade the stock to Underperform, with our unchanged price target of 250p implying ~21% downside from the May 12th closing price of ~315p.

Daily Mail and General Trust (DMGT:LSE): Last: 709.50, down 16.5 (-2.27%), High: 713.50, Low: 708.00, Volume: 109.66k
BE

Barclays worried about the change of management.

BE

Looking at a multi-year picture, the arrival of a new CEO should not be a signal to
downgrade a stock. A new vision can add value, especially where the story is as
complex as DMGT’s. We also continue to like the quality of some assets, especially
in DMG Information and DMG Events – and the valuation for the group may not
reflect this quality. However, looking at relative share price performance of Media
stocks after a new CEO’s announcement suggests that uncertainty on new strategy
and investment makes outperformance over 3 or 6 months unlikely. And in the
short-term, signs from Trinity Mirror and ITV on UK advertising are negative. While
investors may understand this, we are concerned about the exact level of pain for
DMGT’s UK newspapers through the quarter to end of March and since then. They
report 1H (to end March) on 26th May.

11:56 am
BE

Lastly, after recent share price
outperformance (+6% vs FTSE All Share YTD and +7% since start April), we see 8%
upside to our price target. That tweaks up driven by the Zoopla stake, but with
forecasts lowered slightly on FX, we see no justification to raise it further. So we
downgrade DMGT to EW. We prefer Informa (OW) among B2B Media names.

BE

The ads data? Sure. There's a handy summary of what peers have said.

BE

Trinity Mirror: In Trinity’s May IMS, it pointed to print advertising falling 19% from end
December to end April in 2016. Print advertising declined 17.5% in 1H 2015A and 16%
in 2H 2015A. So declines have accelerated somewhat.

11:58 am
BE

ITV: At the FY results, ITV guided to January -1%, February -4%, March +5% and April -
5% and delivered except March (1 point worse) and April (8 points worse). April
weakness came from late money disappearing following the announcement of the UK-
EU referendum date. For Q2, ITV is guiding to -13%, +0% and +15% in April/May/June.
+15% in June is above our latest conversations with media buyers that put June at 5-
10%. Post their Q1 results, we lowered our 2016E ITV Family advertising forecasts to
1.5% from 3.0% for FY 2016E. Excluding UTV, advertising would be down 0.1%.

BE

Channel4: The Channel 4 sales house grew revenues 9% in 2015, and the growth for
Channel 4’s own channels was 5% according to Campaign (May 11, 2016). According
to this interview in Campaign, Channel 4 expects the market to be “probably up 1% or
flat” from April to June (inclusive) despite the Euro 2016 football tournament in June.
This is more conservative than ITV is guiding to on its own channels. The Channel 4
director of sales explained the weaker advertising market as follows: "About a quarter of
it is Brexit. A quarter is supermarkets coming out of advertising. This isn’t just TV. The
grocers are pulling out of the whole ad market and they’re putting a lot of pressure on
the Procter & Gambles and L’Oreals to put money into discounting [on prices] rather
than advertising. But probably half is the general global economy. It’s been quite a tough
year so far, globally."

BE

To us it seems logical that there will be at least a degree of a post referendum advertising
bounce should the UK stay in (of course an uncertainty). But it does seem likely that DMGT
is going to report weak advertising figures for their 1H to end March and then give weak
commentary around April and May trading (which they typically do in these results). We
model a 17% decline in print advertising in 1H 2016E for the Mail and Mail on Sunday titles,
-7% for Metro and growth of 21% for MailOnline.

12:02 pm
BE

Avanti’s Q3 statement has reconfirmed guidance for the year to June. Revenues were up 15% and continuing business revenue for its top twenty customers saw growth of 59%. A continuation of these trends will see cash flow improve materially because of the fixed cost nature of the business. Avanti is on the right side of both the technology and pricing shifts in the marketplace and we remain Buyers.
n Q3 revenues +15%. Revenues in the third quarter of $19.5m increased 15% sequentially. Avanti generated a small positive earnings contribution (EBITDA $0.4m) on higher revenues despite significant higher investment in sales and other headcount over the year.
n $122m gross cash. Capital expenditure on Hylas-4 led to cash consumption of $40m cash in the quarter. The development of Hylas-3 and 4 is fully funded and their expected launches next year will see capex then revert to a maintenance level only of low single digit millions.
n Contract wins. The recent $29m contract win with BT/EE was won against competition from the major players in the industry. The win was secured on pricing terms consistent with Avanti’s targets and the contract helps support the unchanged guidance for the current fiscal period. Avanti has become a provider of critical infrastructure to the emergency services in the UK and the level of due diligence behind this contract should provide great comfort to investors as to the sustainability of Avanti’s business model.
n Industry backdrop. Recent warnings from Eutelsat and Inmarsat have not provided a favourable backdrop for Avanti. Eutelsat lowered its guidance last week to reflect hard comps, lower broadcasting demand and regional weakness in LatAm. Inmarsat warned prior to that on lower aviation, maritime and energy sector demand. None of these service lines provide read-across for Avanti’s segmental offering of data services.
n Price disrupter. New Ka band services such as that from Avanti are dragging average pricing for the industry down. Legacy Ku band pricing of over $4,000 per Mhz is twice the level Avanti charges for its data services. Avanti is the price and quality of service disrupter in the marketplace.
n Operational leverage. Rising revenues, static operating costs and falling capex will see cash flow soon begin to accelerate. We remain Buyers on this basis.
